Description: Tomato mosaic virus is a plant disease that affects tomatoes, causing mosaic-like patterns on the leaves.
Causes: Caused by the Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) or Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV).
Symptoms:
1. Mosaic patterns on leaves
2. Yellowing of leaves
3. Stunted growth
4. Reduced fruit yield
Treatment: No specific cure, remove infected plants to prevent spread.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Use virus-resistant tomato varieties
2. Control aphids and other vectors
3. Sanitize tools and equipment
Prevention: Plant disease-resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and maintain good hygiene.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through contaminated seeds, soil, and tools. Can lead to significant yield losses.

Description: Target spot is a fungal disease affecting tomatoes, characterized by circular lesions on leaves.
Causes: Caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola.
Symptoms:
1. Circular lesions with concentric rings
2. Dark, necrotic spots on leaves
3. Premature defoliation
Treatment: Fungicides containing chlorothalonil can be used for control.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Provide adequate spacing between plants
2. Avoid overhead irrigation
3. Remove and destroy infected leaves
Prevention: Apply fungicides preventatively, practice crop rotation, and maintain proper plant spacing.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through splashing water and can lead to reduced yield and fruit quality.

Description: Bacterial spot is a bacterial disease affecting tomatoes, causing dark, necrotic spots on leaves and fruits.
Causes: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria.
Symptoms:
1. Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruits
2. Lesions with a halo-like appearance
3. Leaf and fruit drop
Treatment: Copper-based bactericides can help control bacterial spot.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Rotate crops to reduce pathogen buildup
2. Use disease-free seeds and transplants
3. Apply copper sprays preventatively
Prevention: Practice crop rotation, use disease-free seeds, and maintain good garden hygiene.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through rain splashes and can lead to significant yield losses.

Description: Tomato yellow leaf curl virus is a viral disease affecting tomatoes, causing yellowing and curling of leaves.
Causes: Caused by Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) and transmitted by whiteflies.
Symptoms:
1. Yellowing and curling of leaves
2. Leaf narrowing
3. Reduced fruit size and yield
Treatment: No cure, control whiteflies using insecticides.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Use insecticides to control whiteflies
2. Plant virus-resistant tomato varieties
3. Remove infected plants
Prevention: Control whitefly populations, plant resistant varieties, and maintain good garden hygiene.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread by whiteflies and can cause severe yield losses.

Description: Late blight is a fungal disease affecting tomatoes, causing dark lesions on leaves and fruits.
Causes: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.
Symptoms:
1. Dark lesions on leaves and fruits
2. White fungal growth under humid conditions
3. Rapid plant defoliation
Treatment: Fungicides containing metalaxyl can help control late blight.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Provide good air circulation
2. Avoid overhead irrigation
3. Apply fungicides preventatively
Prevention: Apply fungicides preventatively, practice crop rotation, and monitor for early symptoms.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through spores and can cause rapid and severe damage to plants.

Description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease affecting tomatoes, characterized by yellowing and mold growth on leaves.
Causes: Caused by the fungus Fulvia fulva.
Symptoms:
1. Yellowing of leaves
2. Velvety, greenish-black mold growth on the undersides of leaves
Treatment: Fungicides containing chlorothalonil can help control leaf mold.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Provide good air circulation
2. Avoid overhead irrigation
3. Apply fungicides preventatively
Prevention: Apply fungicides preventatively, maintain proper spacing, and monitor for early symptoms.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through spores and can lead to reduced fruit quality.

Description: Early blight is a fungal disease affecting tomatoes, causing concentric rings of dark lesions on leaves.
Causes: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani.
Symptoms:
1. Dark lesions with concentric rings on leaves
2. Lower leaf yellowing and defoliation
3. Reduced fruit yield
Treatment: Fungicides containing chlorothalonil can help control early blight.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Remove infected plant debris
2. Apply fungicides preventatively
3. Provide proper plant spacing
Prevention: Practice crop rotation, use disease-resistant varieties, and monitor for early symptoms.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through spores and can lead to significant yield losses.

Description: Two-spotted spider mites are arachnids that feed on tomato plants, causing stippling and discoloration of leaves.
Causes: Caused by the spider mite Tetranychus urticae.
Symptoms:
1. Stippling on leaves
2. Webbing on the undersides of leaves
3. Yellowing and discoloration
Treatment: Miticides can help control spider mite infestations.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Introduce predatory mites
2. Use insecticidal soaps
3. Maintain proper humidity levels
Prevention: Regularly inspect plants for mites, provide adequate humidity, and avoid over-fertilization.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through wind and can lead to reduced plant vigor.

Description: A healthy tomato plant with no signs of diseases.
Prevention: Practice proper plant hygiene and provide optimal growing conditions.
Spread_and_Impact: No impact, represents a disease-free state.

Description: Septoria leaf spot is a fungal disease affecting tomatoes, causing small, dark spots on leaves.
Causes: Caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici.
Symptoms:
1. Small, dark spots with white centers on leaves
2. Premature defoliation
Treatment: Fungicides containing chlorothalonil can help control septoria leaf spot.
MANAGEMENT_TIPS:
1. Remove infected plant debris
2. Apply fungicides preventatively
3. Provide proper plant spacing
Prevention: Practice crop rotation, use disease-resistant varieties, and monitor for early symptoms.
Spread_and_Impact: Spread through spores and can lead to reduced fruit quality.
